title: Char Siu Noodle Bowl
description: Savory-sweet char siu pork glazed with a honey-soy marinade, thinly sliced and served over springy wheat noodles with bright greens and scallions. The bowl balances caramelized pork, umami broth, and a quick pickled cucumber for contrast.

steps.text: Make the char siu marinade by whisking together soy sauce, hoisin, honey, mirin, shaoxing wine, minced garlic, grated ginger, five-spice powder and optional food coloring in a bowl until smooth.

Reserve one-quarter of the marinade in a separate bowl for glazing later; add the pork strips to the remaining marinade, massaging to coat, then cover and refrigerate for at least 4 hours or up to overnight for best flavor.

Preheat oven to 200째C / 400째F. Remove pork from marinade, wipe off excess marinade to prevent burning, then heat oil in a heavy skillet over medium-high heat and sear pork strips 1-2 minutes per side until browned to develop color.

Transfer seared pork to a foil-lined baking sheet or roasting rack, brush with reserved glaze, roast in the preheated oven until internal temperature reaches 70째C / 160째F and edges start to caramelize, about 20-25 minutes, flipping and glazing once halfway through.
While pork roasts, quick-pickle the cucumber by combining rice vinegar and sugar, stirring until dissolved, then tossing with sliced cucumber and letting sit at room temperature for 10 minutes.
Bring the broth to a gentle simmer in a medium saucepan, season with salt and pepper, then blanch halved bok choy in the simmering broth for 1-2 minutes until bright and tender; remove and keep warm.

Cook the wheat noodles according to package instructions until just al dente, usually 3-5 minutes for fresh noodles or 7-9 minutes for dried; drain and toss lightly with a small amount of sesame oil to prevent sticking.
When pork is done, rest for 5 minutes, then thinly slice on a bias. Rewarm reserved glaze briefly and brush over slices for extra shine.

Assemble bowls by dividing noodles among bowls, ladling warm broth if using, arranging sliced char siu on top with bok choy, pickled cucumber, and scallions. Drizzle sesame oil and optional chili oil, sprinkle toasted sesame seeds, and serve immediately.
